Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Multi-Modal Digital Footprints to Infer Public Sentiment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social science takes as axiomatic that agents act on beliefs: however, teasing out the correlations between belief and action is no simple feat. Traditionally, social scientists relied on survey data to measure sentiment that might indicate changing economic trends, and on lab experiments to test actions given manipulated beliefs. Surveys, however, are notoriously expensive to scale, difficult to conduct frequently, and possess bias; lab experiments artificially constrain decision-making and thus fail to capture the complex dependencies of real-world actions.

This project will generate measurements of public sentiment directly from the actions of people, using one of the largest datasets of human behavior ever studied: online opinions expressed on platforms like Twitter or comments posted on news websites, time series representing the volume of search queries on Google, and call detail records. Using these digital footprints, the project will develop new social-computational measures of public sentiments related to the state of the economy, expected unemployment, and concerns about national priorities.

Broader impacts: The project will offer new alternatives to surveys as a measure of public sentiment, and will also generate unprecedented insight into the online and onsite behavior of the American population. This research also has the potential to help public and private organizations better understand the dynamic behaviors of customers and constituents, and to make business and policy decisions informed by economic trends derived from data. The project will enhance education through the interdisciplinary training of graduate students. Both graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be actively encouraged to participate in the project. A public website will also be set up detailing the project results.

Data analysis from CDR Mobile phone records to quantify dynamics in specific populations.  Learn how aggregate populations behave using moblie data as a lens.  Publications include Scaling identity connects human mobility and social interactions. Publications include Airtime transfers. Air time transfers and mobile communications : Evidencee in the aftermath of natural disasters. Quantifying seasonal population fluxes driving rubella transmission dynamics using phone data.  Measures of human mobility using mobile phone records enhanced with GIS data. Evaluating spatial interaction models for regional mobility in sub-Saharan Africa. Spatiotemporal detection of unusual human population behavior using mobile phone data.

This project aims to generate measurements of consumer sentiment directly from the actions of people, using what we believe to be one of the largest datasets of human behavior ever studied: online opinions expressed on communication platforms like Twitter or comments posted on news websites like the New York Times and the Huffington Post, time series representing the volume of search queries on Google, and call detail records of over 20 million americans. Using only these digital footprints, we propose to characterize and understand new social-computational measures of consumer sentiments related to the state of the economy, expected unemployment, approval of the presidential administration, and concerns about national priorities. We believe this work will not only offer an alternative to surveys as a measure of consumer sentiment, but will also generate unprecedented insight into the online and onsite behavior of the American population.
